headline: A giant turned into a sinking boat
pros:
Colleagues are great, talented people are willing to help each other to overcome the company poor decisions.
It's the perfect environment to get your hands dirty, as far as you can avoid the political side of the company.
The office is great, although located in West London which makes commuting tricky for people coming from east.
The discount benefit is quite good (40% on every website), although only applicable on items that have been on the website for more than few months, so not useful for exclusive sales or new collections.
Work life balance is good, working tends to be quite relaxed as every single task or project is generally blocked for months behind bureaucracy.
cons:
A mix of an ego driven CEO with no experience and the Richemont acquisition, led the company to the worst period in 10 years. What was a giant before, now it's a sinking ship without a plan to recover.
Many years of budget cuts removed every perk of being employed by YNAP, no more allowances, party budgets, learning budgets, but mostly headcount budget.
The company lost around 35% of the whole engineering department within the last 18 months, praised bonus were cancelled for many years, promised promotions were postponed for even more, there's no room for growth and the result is that the most talented people, the ones that really wanted to help, have been forced to change job. The few talents that are still in YNAP are basically searching for other opportunities and the others that made their career just because of time, high-ladder friendships or because they were always answering yes to their manages are staying and taking the decisions that are crippling the business. 
The HR department is inadequate to say the least, with few episodes of reported mobbing. Every single employee complaining on daily basis and the morale is on an all time low.
The new acquirer Richemont doesn't see any value in the company and have no projects or budget for it.
The CEO is an old school person that in the middle of pandemic wanted everyone to go back to the office.
The finance department is detached from reality and willing to fire a consultant from a day to another to fix the budget, while leaving entire departments without knowledge and with months worth of incidents to solve.
There's also a big bias problem where the Italian employees don't want to work with the British ones and they refuse to involve them because of the country they are located in.

Lack of decision making and therefore everything is slow and again makes the business not agile at all.
Richemont did not help the company as they are completely digitally and tech illiterate. Most people barely understand luxury. 
In terms of compensation and salaries, YNAP will offer way below market compensation with not so interesting benefits.

If you are looking for an interesting tech/digital business, I would say run away as you will end up with a traditional retailer.

headline: Emotional Torture
pros:
trips to italy
discounts on clothing
show up and leave whenever you like, never have to do a full days work
cons:
I can honestly say YNAP was one of, if not the worst experience of my professional life.
whether it be the rapid loss of skills I experienced whilst trying to work with *really* poorly implemented tech solutions by engineers who have never attempted to implement something before, or any understanding of what problem said solution is there to solve. Managers who haven't considered "why" when choosing a solution and "who" when choosing someone to implement said solution.

You will find that YNAP have almost all the tools you could possibly need, all implemented on top of one another. Except you can't configure them to suit your needs. You'll need to work with something that someone else has implemented with no experience and no exposure to the data you are working with or any willingness to listen to why you want to alter it, or the benefits it can bring.
You'll experience a culture where contractors are treated as untouchable and have built systems in a manner which keep them in a job. Contractors who can happily refuse to carry out tasks they don't consider valuable use of their time or the direction they want to go in. One time I was pulled into a room and asked to justify my position (to a contractor)

I experienced an extremely toxic culture whilst i was there, where every little thing was reported to management, who left me to rot in a corner to the point i essentially shut down by the end of my tenure. I had to take time off ill with stress with bullying and emotional torture common place if you don't fit the bill of who they want.  in my times confiding with other people from different departments, it was reiterated to me time and time again that the experience I was going through was not uncommon around the business.

Their tech stack is just awful! Time after time, I found myself constantly shaking my head in disbelief as I witnessed manually updating files in place on cloud systems, with no version control or audit trail or notification pipelines. Automation tools exist but they are bypassed regularly. IT Security is almost non-existant, with a blanket level of either prod or non-prod access and no granularity beyond that. If you take IT security seriously, this is definitely not the place for you.

There was zero social budget or training budget, I had to open my personal Online Training account up to one of my team, because the level of AWS knowledge was so low in the department and I was refused any budget to enroll him onto Pluralsight or Linux Academy

The NAP/Yoox (UK/Italy) divide is toxic. The company changes things for the sake of changing. Things are also changed to be in line with Yoox processes which 90% of the time make no logical sense. Italians need to stop trying to enforce their rules on regions that do not follow the same rules/laws/cultures. NAP was the more successful business prior to the merger - so who in their right mind had the bright idea of following the Yoox model?!

Zero transparency or autonomy.

Retention rate of staff is appalling.

headline: BEWARE: Scathing Review

-Health benefits and 401K
-More PTO than most places
-Higher pay in entry level roles relative to other companies
cons:
Where to begin?

-Parking at the DC is never going to change. Limited spots means anyone that gets to the location between 8AM and 3PM are likely to have to park at the park nearby. You're lucky to find any legal parking between then. Employees do need to give up on this ever changing
-All that has been bred with the company growing and changing is an air of hostility toward peers and managers. Supervisors sit around and talk among themselves about gossip, weddings, pregnancies and people. They try to compete with one another while acting like they are friends face-to-face. It's constant trying to up one another on some superficial status in their lives.  Main point of bringing this up is that it affects your employees. If anyone is actually requiring help or assistance from a supervisor/senior, no one is available at their desk to help. If this is ever brought up as some sort of feedback, you're criticized, judged or condemned. They'll either make an excuse like "well you could have interrupted or come found one of us" or "you could have asked someone else" or even "oh, sorry, I was just so busy. Can you send an email for us to do later?" I'm sorry but if you've been put into a higher position, you should be available to do your job. In no way should your team members or employees feel as though they are inconveniencing you for doing your job that you are paid more to do. Also you're lucky if you even find a manager who knows what they're doing. Some do not even know how to use their phone or write grammatically correct emails.
-With the above, the environment is maybe middle school or 9th grade level at best. You have a bunch of grown adults who act like children.
-They hire based on connections or how willing you are to suck up. It's not oblivious to the floor. Everyone knows the last few who have been put into higher positions should have had no place in being hired. If you cannot action basic functions like transferring a call or creating a basic UPS return label, how can anyone trust you to do any actual complex functions?
-On the opposite end, the place is hiring people who don't even know how to use computers. We are an internet company.

pros:

cons:
Environment
Uninvolved management 
Culture 

Through no fault of my own, a coworker in the warehouse assumed I was friendly with someone she was having personal issues with. In front of everyone, she verbally harrased me and threatened to beat me to a pulp, and I had never once spoken to this person before. The managers were not there and didn't even notice. Thankfully another coworker restrained this woman. She was suspended with pay for a week, and allowed to come work the same shifts as me. Never once was I explained the situation nor did they have the decency to allow me to sit down with this person so we could mediate what had occurred. She  was very hostile toward me even coming back, even though I tried to be friendly because I was scared of what would happen. I immediately asked the managers to switch my schedule, this manager DENIED being able to do so even when I had asked coworkers and they had confirmed she was the person to go to for this. To this day I simply cannot fathom how they allowed this woman with a previous criminal record to get away with this. I never showed up to work after that and was unemployed for a few months because of this sudden situation. 

The starting pay at the warehouse positions was $15-$20 five years ago, the more time passes they lower the salary and the amount that is given in raises. This is in addition to much higher copada if you want to enroll in their health insurance. It is a given you will have to work overtime regularly if you want to afford any benefits. Lastly, the main location in mahwah is very difficult to get to if you do not have a car. There are no busses or trains nearby, and it is a regular problem by which employees of the surrounding area need to seek friends or Uber to bring them. $12 starting, with $0.50 - $1 raises every six months is not enough to pay for a car and all bills at 40 hours a week!

headline: Challenging, but in a bad way
pros:
Most of the software that is being written to replace our legacy stack is cutting-edge, an approach that has been followed with the utmost pragmatism. This includes Scala microservices and full-stack JavaScript software that runs on Amazon Web Services. On top of that, the Westfield office is lovely, and I work with some fun, knowledgeable people.

There are societies that are funded by the company. These include board games and 5-a-side footy.

Before merging with Yoox, we also had a pretty good culture. We'd have lavish summer and Christmas parties, as well as quarterly parties in the office. There was also more budget to send developers to conferences.
cons:
It's worth mentioning prior to discussing the post-merger environment, that a lot of the old staff members who have left, such as architects, made some very poor technical decisions. This often results in the new team members having to pick up the pieces and rectify everything. Furthermore, we're still massively dependent upon our legacy tech stack. This often hits us when we're on compulsory support (which is admittedly normal these days.)

Since merging with Yoox, the company feels more like a corporation than a larger, successful startup. The new executive team is attempting to replace our new backend services with IBM WebSphere, a monolith that regresses a lot when compared to even our legacy stack, and is simply being shoehorned into the company without good technical reason. Adding to the corporate feel is the use of words such as "synergies, "synergetic", and "at scale". These words were never uttered before the merger, but thanks to the execs, almost everyone in the business now uses these terms. It's small things like this that are causing the cultural change.

On one occasion, I was informed that I would not receive budget for a conference that I wished to attend, because there was a similar one locally. I initially accepted this, but soon realised that the company was sponsoring this alternative, thus the tickets were free. I appreciate this doesn't matter in the grand scheme of things, but it doesn't make one feel valued.

And on that note, the parties have stopped, with the excuse of "the company is too big now, so organise such shindigs within your own department". The executives in my area have been silent on this matter, thus have used it as an excuse to save money. The quarterly in-office parties have also stopped without any mention. Again, these may be first world problems, but they have effectively destroyed the company's culture and are making the staff feel undervalued.

Also, the business doesn't understand that Yoox-NAP is also a technology company. They claim to be agile, although their definition equates to being able to add business requirements, about which they've sometimes forgotten, at the last minute, while respecting the already-established deadline. Trying to explain the concept of an MVP is futile, with the usual response being "this feature must go live as our brand could be damaged" (which simply isn't true,) as well as "this isn't an MVP, but an MMP" (Minimum Marketable Product - read: we can ask for whatever we want with an unmovable deadline.)
